article_title: Debate Over NYC Sodium Menu Labeling Gets Salty
article_text:
Debate Over NYC Sodium Menu Labeling Gets Salty

Law360, New York (October 7, 2015, 5:33 PM ET) -- Laura Venker



Melvin S. Drozen On Sept. 9, 2015, the New York City Board of Health unanimously passed regulations making New York the first U.S. city to require restaurants to disclose to diners those menu items that contain more than 2,300 milligrams of sodium, or the equivalent of about one teaspoon of salt.



Under the newly-adopted regulations, all chain restaurants — defined as those having 15 or more locations nationwide — must add a salt-shaker-like symbol on menus next to products that contain more than 2,300...

article_metadata.description: In September, New York City became the first U.S. city to require chain restaurants to disclose menu items that  contain more than about one teaspoon of salt. This is not quite in line with the Affordable Care Act's menu labeling requirements and, as opponents of the rule will gladly point out, may run into federal preemption problems, say Laura Venker and Mel Drozen at Keller & Heckman LLP.
